sen.j: 今井 宗久（いまい そうきゅう、1520年（永正17年） - 1593年8月31日（文禄2年8月5日 (旧暦)））は、安土桃山時代の堺の商人、茶人である。
sen.e: Sokyu IMAI (1520-August 31, 1593) was a merchant of Sakai and a chajin (master of the tea ceremony), who lived in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
Sokyu IMAI (1520 - August 31, 1593) was a merchant in Sakai and a chajin (master of the tea ceremony), who lived in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
Sokyu IMAI (1520 - August 31, 1593) was a merchant in Sakai and a chajin (master of the tea ceremony), who lived in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

sen.j: 子に今井宗薫。
sen.e: Sokyu had a son whose name was Sokun IMAI.
Sokun IMAI was his son.
Sokun IMAI was his son.

sen.j: 家系は尼子氏の一族とも。
sen.e: Sokyu's family line can trace back to the Amago clan.
His family line can trace back to the Amago clan.
His family line can trace back to the Amago clan.

sen.j: 千利休、津田宗及と共に茶の「三大宗匠」と称せられた。
sen.e: Sokyu IMAI, SEN no Rikyu and Sogyu TSUDA were collectively called the 'three great tea masters.'
He was called 'three great tea masters' along with SEN no Rikyu and Sogyu TSUDA.
He was called 'three great tea masters' along with SEN no Rikyu and Sogyu TSUDA.

sen.j: 名は彦右衛門兼員、号は昨夢斎。
sen.e: Sokyu's common name was Hikoemon Kanekazu, and Sakumusai was his 'saigo' (which was a name to be given when entering Buddhist priesthood; the name of a room ['sai'] to be given to a monk practicing asceticism indicated the monk himself).
sen.cmt: 「昨夢斎」の読み不明。恐らく「さくむさい」だと思われます。また、名は「彦右衛門、兼員」とありましたが、「彦右衛門兼員」と続ける例がありましたので、それを採用致しました。「号」は「斎号」を指すことを訳出しました。斎号とは、「得度の際、師より授かる仏弟子としての名前。「斎」は本来部屋を意味し、修行のため与えられた室号がその人自身を指す名前となった。」(http://web-japan.org/kidsweb/ja/meet/chado/chado08.html#saigo)とあります。
sen.e: Sokyu's common name was Hikoemon Kanekazu, and his posthumous name was Sakumusai (昨夢斎).
sen.cmt: 表現を変え、読み不明の漢字を補足しました。
sen.e: Sokyu's common name was Hikoemon Kanekazu, and his posthumous name was Sakumusai (昨夢斎).

sen.j: 屋号は納屋。
sen.e: His house name was Naya.
sen.cmt: 屋号は、「納屋」が特別な堺商人の身分を示す「納屋衆」のことである為 trade nameとも考えられますが、家号 house nameの可能性もあります。尚、右記百科事典の記載では明らかに「家号」とありますので、ここではそれに従い訳出しました。http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/%E4%BB%8A%E4%BA%95%E5%AE%97%E4%B9%85/
sen.e: His yago (the name of the store) was Naya.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。
sen.e: His yago (the name of the store) was Naya.

sen.j: 来歴
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 大和国（奈良県）今井町の出身。
sen.e: Sokyu IMAI was from Imai-cho, Yamato Province (Nara Prefecture).
He was from Imai Town, Yamato Province (Nara Prefecture).
He was from Imai Town, Yamato Province (Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: 祖は近江佐々木氏の末裔で近江国高島郡の今井氏という。
sen.e: His ancestors descended from the Sasaki clan of Omi Province, whose name was the Imai clan of Takashima-gun County in Omi Province.
His ancestor was descended from the Sasaki clan of Omi Province, called the Imai clan of Takashima County in Omi Province.
His ancestor was descended from the Sasaki clan of Omi Province, called the Imai clan of Takashima County in Omi Province.

sen.j: 堺に出て納屋宗次の居宅に身を寄せ、武野紹鴎に茶を学ぶ。
sen.e: Sokyu moved to Sakai where he stayed at Munetsugu NAYA's house and learned 'chanoyu' (the tea ceremony) under Joo TAKENO.
sen.cmt: 「宗次」の読み不明。同時代人に甲良宗次（こうら・むねつぐ）がある為、それに準じます。（明治・大正時代の人名では「そうじ」の読みもあります。）http://kotobank.jp/word/%E7%94%B2%E8%89%AF%E5%AE%97%E6%AC%A1
sen.e: Sokyu moved to Sakai where he stayed at Munetsugu (宗次) NAYA's house and learned 'chanoyu' (the tea ceremony) under Joo TAKENO.
sen.cmt: 読み不明の漢字を補足しました。
sen.e: Sokyu moved to Sakai where he stayed at Munetsugu (宗次) NAYA's house and learned 'chanoyu' (the tea ceremony) under Joo TAKENO.

sen.j: やがて紹鴎の女婿となり、茶器などを譲り受けたという。
sen.e: Thereafter, Sokyu married Joo's daughter and inherited Joo's tea utensils.
Thereafter, Sokyu married Joo's daughter and inherited Joo's tea utensils.
Thereafter, Sokyu married Joo's daughter and inherited Joo's tea utensils.

sen.j: 1554年（天文 (日本)23年）には大徳寺塔頭大僊院に百七十貫を寄進している。
sen.e: In 1554, Sokyu donated 170 kan to Daisenin which is a 'tacchu' (branch temple) of Daitoku-ji Temple.
In 1554, Sokyu donated 170 kan (a unit of currency) to Daisenin which was a tatchu (branch temple) of Daitoku-ji Temple.
In 1554, Sokyu donated 170 kan (a unit of currency) to Daisenin which was a tatchu (branch temple) of Daitoku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 初めは当時軍需品としての需要があった鹿皮などの皮製品（甲冑製造などに用いる）の販売を扱っており、それによって財をなしたのみならず、各地の戦国大名とのつながりを深めていくきっかけとなった。
sen.e: Sokyu initially conducted business of selling leather goods such as deerskin (to be used in producing armor, for instance), which were demanded munitions around that time, thereby not only making a fortune but giving him more opportunities to strengthen ties with Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lords in the Sengoku period) around the country.

Sokyu initially conducted business of selling leather goods such as deerskin (to be used in producing armor, for instance), which were demanded munitions around that time, thereby not only making a fortune but giving him more opportunities to strengthen ties with Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lords in the Sengoku period) in many provinces.

Sokyu initially conducted business of selling leather goods such as deerskin (to be used in producing armor, for instance), which were demanded munitions around that time, thereby not only making a fortune but giving him more opportunities to strengthen ties with Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lords in the Sengoku period) in many provinces.

sen.j: 1568年（永禄11年）10月、上洛した織田信長に摂津国西成郡芥川で相見え、名物の松島の茶壺や紹鴎茄子などを献上。
sen.e: In October, 1568, Sokyu went to Akutagawa, Nishinari-gori County, Settsu Province to meet Nobunaga ODA, who had entered Kyoto, so as to present some 'meibutsu' (famous tea utensils) including a 'chatsubo' (tea urn) which was named Matsushima and 'Joo Nasu' (an eggplant-shaped tea container which was formerly owned by Joo TAKENO).

In October, 1568, Sokyu went to Akutagawa, Nishinari County, Settsu Province to meet Nobunaga ODA, who had entered Kyoto, so as to present some famous tea utensils including a famous tea jar named Matsushima and Joo Nasu (specialty of a tea container), and so on.
sen.cmt: 用語集などに合わせました。
sen.e: In October, 1568, Sokyu went to Akutagawa, Nishinari County, Settsu Province to meet Nobunaga ODA, who had entered Kyoto, so as to present some famous tea utensils including a famous tea jar named Matsushima and Joo Nasu (specialty of a tea container), and so on.

sen.j: いち早く信長の知己を得て、足利義昭からは大蔵卿法印の位を授かる。
sen.e: In doing so, Sokyu quickly got acquainted with Nobunaga, and was granted an official rank of Okura-kyo hoin (the highest rank among Buddhist priests of the Minister of the Treasury) by Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA.

In doing so, Sokyu quickly got acquainted with Nobunaga, and was granted the title of Hoin (a title for doctors, painters, sculptors, and so on, adopted by the Buddhist highest rank in the hierarchy) of Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury) by Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA.

In doing so, Sokyu quickly got acquainted with Nobunaga, and was granted the title of Hoin (a title for doctors, painters, sculptors, and so on, adopted by the Buddhist highest rank in the hierarchy) of Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury) by Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 同年、信長が堺に対して矢銭二万貫を課した際、会合衆たちが三好氏の力を背景に徹底抗戦の姿勢を見せたのに対し、宗久はこの要求を受け入れるよう信長と会合衆の仲介を行い、これに成功する。
sen.e: In the same year (1568), when Nobunaga imposed 'yasen' (war funds) of 20,000 kan on Sakai, 'Egoshu' (wealthy marchants who led self-governing organizations) with backing of the Miyoshi clan, displayed do-or-die resistance, but Sokyu persuaded them to accept Nobunaga's demand and succeeded in mediating that conflict between Nobunaga and the Egoshu.

In the same year (1568), when Nobunaga imposed Yasen (war funds) of 20,000 kan on Sakai, Egoshu (wealthy merchants who led self-governing organizations) with backing of the Miyoshi clan, displayed do-or-die resistance, but Sokyu persuaded them to accept Nobunaga's demand and succeeded in mediating that conflict between Nobunaga and the Egoshu.

In the same year (1568), when Nobunaga imposed Yasen (war funds) of 20,000 kan on Sakai, Egoshu (wealthy merchants who led self-governing organizations) with backing of the Miyoshi clan, displayed do-or-die resistance, but Sokyu persuaded them to accept Nobunaga's demand and succeeded in mediating that conflict between Nobunaga and the Egoshu.

sen.j: これ以降、宗久は信長に重用され、さまざまな特権を得る。
sen.e: Thereafter, Nobunaga started to treat Sokyu preferentially, so that Sokyu obtained various privileges.
Thereafter, Nobunaga started to treat Sokyu preferentially, so that Sokyu obtained various privileges.
Thereafter, Nobunaga started to treat Sokyu preferentially, so that Sokyu obtained various privileges.

sen.j: 1569年（永禄12年）には、堺近郊にある摂津五カ庄の塩・塩合物の徴収権と代官職、淀過書船の利用（淀川の通行権）を得て、1570年（元亀元年）には長谷川宗仁とともに生野銀山などの但馬銀山を支配する。
sen.e: In 1569, Sokyu gained the right to levy a tax of salt and chloride compound as well as the post of 'daikan' (local governor) of Settsu Gokasho (five private lands of Settsu Province), and the right to use 'Yodo Kashobune' (the right of boats that run regularly on the Yodo-gawa river), and in 1570 Sokyu and Sonin HASEGAWA controlled the Tajima-ginzan silver mines including the Ikuno-ginzan silver mine.

In 1569, Sokyu gained the right to levy a tax of salt and chloride compound as well as the post of daikan (local governor) of Settsu Gokasho (five private lands of Settsu Province), and the right to use Yodo Kashobune (the right of boats that run regularly on the Yodo-gawa river), and in 1570 Sokyu and Sonin HASEGAWA controlled the Tajima-ginzan silver mines including the Ikuno-ginzan silver mine.

In 1569, Sokyu gained the right to levy a tax of salt and chloride compound as well as the post of daikan (local governor) of Settsu Gokasho (five private lands of Settsu Province), and the right to use Yodo Kashobune (the right of boats that run regularly on the Yodo-gawa river), and in 1570 Sokyu and Sonin HASEGAWA controlled the Tajima-ginzan silver mines including the Ikuno-ginzan silver mine.

sen.j: また、代官領に河内鋳物師ら吹屋（鍛冶屋）を集め、鉄砲や火薬製造にも携わった。
sen.e: In addition, Sokyu gathered 'fukiya' (blacksmiths) including Kawachi imonoshi (casters of Kawachi Province) within his daikan-ryo (territory of the local governor), dealing with manufacture of guns and gunpowder.
In addition, Sokyu gathered Fukiya (blacksmiths) including casters in Kawachi Province within his territory, dealing with manufacture of guns and gunpowder.
In addition, Sokyu gathered Fukiya (blacksmiths) including casters in Kawachi Province within his territory, dealing with manufacture of guns and gunpowder.

sen.j: これらにより、会合衆の中でも抜き出た存在として堺での立場を確実なものにし、信長の天下統一を支えた。
sen.e: Thus, Sokyu dominated the other Egoshu members based on his unchallenged standing at Sakai, thereby assisting Nobunaga's unification of the whole country.
Thus, Sokyu dominated the other Egoshu members based on his unchallenged standing at Sakai, thereby assisting Nobunaga's unification of the whole country.
Thus, Sokyu dominated the other Egoshu members based on his unchallenged standing at Sakai, thereby assisting Nobunaga's unification of the whole country.

sen.j: また、茶人としても千利休、津田宗及とともに信長の茶頭を務めた。
sen.e: Also, being a tea master, Sokyu served as Nobunaga's 'sado' (person in charge of the tea ceremony) along with SEN no Rikyu and Sogyu TSUDA.
Also, being a tea master, Sokyu served as Nobunaga's sado (person in charge of the tea ceremony) along with SEN no Rikyu and Sogyu TSUDA.
Also, being a tea master, Sokyu served as Nobunaga's sado (person in charge of the tea ceremony) along with SEN no Rikyu and Sogyu TSUDA.

sen.j: 信長の死後には羽柴秀吉（後の豊臣秀吉）にも仕え、堺の万台屋宗安、住吉屋宗無とともに秀吉の御咄衆を務めた。
sen.e: After the death of Nobunaga, Sokyu served Hideyoshi HASHIBA (to be Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI later) as one of his 'Ohanashi-shu' (collocutors of the Lord) which included Soan MOZUYA and Somu SUMIYOSHIYA of Sakai.
After the death of Nobunaga, Sokyu served Hideyoshi HASHIBA (later Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) as one of his Ohanashi-shu (collocutors of the Lord) which included Soan MOZUYA and Somu SUMIYOSHIYA of Sakai.
After the death of Nobunaga, Sokyu served Hideyoshi HASHIBA (later Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) as one of his Ohanashi-shu (collocutors of the Lord) which included Soan MOZUYA and Somu SUMIYOSHIYA of Sakai.

sen.j: また茶頭として1587年（天正15年）に秀吉が主催した聚楽第落成の交歓茶事北野大茶会にも協力をする。
sen.e: Sokyu, as Hideyoshi's sado, worked in cooperation for the tea ceremony of the Great Kitano Tea Gathering so as to celebrate the inauguration of Jurakudai (which was Hideyoshi's residence and office in Kyoto).

Sokyu, as Hideyoshi's sado, worked in cooperation for the tea ceremony of the Great Kitano Tea Gathering so as to celebrate the inauguration of Jurakudai (which was Hideyoshi's residence and office in Kyoto) in 1587.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「1587年」を補足しました。
sen.e: Sokyu, as Hideyoshi's sado, worked in cooperation for the tea ceremony of the Great Kitano Tea Gathering so as to celebrate the inauguration of Jurakudai (which was Hideyoshi's residence and office in Kyoto) in 1587.

sen.j: しかし、秀吉は宗久よりも新興の薬種商・小西隆佐や千利休らを重用したため、信長時代に浴したほどの地位ではなかったと考えられている。
sen.e: Hideyoshi, however, treated Ryusa KONISHI, who was an emerging second-class drug seller, and SEN no Rikyu more preferentially than Sokyu, it is likely that Sokyu's position under Hideyoshi's regime was not as high as the one granted by Nobunaga.

Hideyoshi, however, treated Ryusa KONISHI, who was an emerging second-class drug seller, and SEN no Rikyu more preferentially than Sokyu, it is likely that Sokyu's position under Hideyoshi's regime was not as high as the one granted by Nobunaga.

Hideyoshi, however, treated Ryusa KONISHI, who was an emerging second-class drug seller, and SEN no Rikyu more preferentially than Sokyu, it is likely that Sokyu's position under Hideyoshi's regime was not as high as the one granted by Nobunaga.

sen.j: 1593年（文禄2年）に死去、享年73。
sen.e: Sokyu died in 1593, at the age of 73.
He died in 1593, at the age of 73.
He died in 1593, at the age of 73.

sen.j: 著作に茶会記録の『今井宗久茶湯書抜』や『今井宗久日記』など。
sen.e: Sokyu's writing includes "Imai Sokyu Chanoyu Kakinuki" (Excerpts from the Tea Ceremony of Sokyu IMAI) and "Imai Sokyu Nikki" (The Diary of Sokyu IMAI).
sen.cmt: 『今井宗久茶湯書抜』 "Imai Sokyu Chanoyu Kakinuki" (Excerpts from the Tea Ceremony of Sokyu IMAI) http://base1.nijl.ac.jp/infolib/meta_pub/KTGSearch.cgi （日本古典籍総合目録）当該データベースに『今井宗久日記』が見つかりません。http://juc.lib.cam.ac.uk/spcat/spcat.cgi?mode=3&BID=BN02188443&country=eng ここでは原文通りに訳出してあります。
sen.e: His writings are included a report of the tea ceremony "Imai Sokyu Chanoyu Kakinuki" (Excerpts from the Tea Ceremony of Sokyu IMAI) and "Imai Sokyu Nikki" (The Diary of Sokyu IMAI).
His writings are included a report of the tea ceremony "Imai Sokyu Chanoyu Kakinuki" (Excerpts from the Tea Ceremony of Sokyu IMAI) and "Imai Sokyu Nikki" (The Diary of Sokyu IMAI).

sen.j: 墓所は大阪府堺市の臨江寺にある。
sen.e: Sokyu's grave is located in Rinko-ji Temple in Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture.
Sokyu's grave is located in Rinko-ji Temple in Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture.
Sokyu's grave is located in Rinko-ji Temple in Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture.

sen.j: 今井宗久設計の大和国今井町の牧村家にあった茶室「黄梅庵」が現在、堺市の大仙公園に在る。
sen.e: The 'Obaian' tea house which was designed by Sokyu IMAI and was owned by the Makimura family of Imai-cho, Yamato Province is well conserved in the Daisen-koen Park in Sakai City today.
The 'Obaian' tea house which was designed by Sokyu IMAI and was owned by the Makimura family of Imai Town, Yamato Province is well conserved in the Daisen-koen Park in Sakai City today.
The 'Obaian' tea house which was designed by Sokyu IMAI and was owned by the Makimura family of Imai Town, Yamato Province is well conserved in the Daisen-koen Park in Sakai City today.
